Here is an initial assesment of possible binary format parsers.

Word Documents:

There are several choices here, though the seemingly obvious choice (and 
defacto standard) is the Apache Jakarta POI project.  It'll do Word, as 
well as several other MS formats, and looks mature.

  http://jakarta.apache.org/poi/

This is available under the apache liscense.

PDF Documents:

There are also a number of pdf readers for java and this choice seems to 
be slightly less obvious.  The most promising choices are as follows.

iText - This is a very mature pdf reader/writer and is available under the 
LGPL.  Of note, this is used by the Alexa toolbar.

  http://www.lowagie.com/iText/

PDFBox - This is a fairly young and basic pdf processor, but it proports 
to extract text, and the bare-bones nature may be an asset if we start 
thinking about performance.  This is made available under the BSD license.

  http://pdfbox.org/

There were several others, but they seemed to be less desirable for a
number of reasons.  Specifically, most had overly restrictive licenses, or
were pre-1.0 releases.

Flash:

There was only one Java package I found that was available for free that 
may do what we're looking for here.  It is called javaswf, and can be 
found here:

  http://www.anotherbigidea.com/javaswf/

It looks like nothing has happened with the project in about a year, so
it's safe to assume we'd be taking this as-is.  Since it's in alpha that
may not be workable, but then again it may beat starting from scratch if
we decide this is a must-have.  It's available under a modified BSD
license that should meet our needs in the even we do want to use it.


That is an initial survey.  If anyone has comments on software I should 
take a(nother) look at that would be great.  Also, it might be useful to 
expand this discussion to other popular formats.  Any other formats we 
want to consider at the moment?  It occurs to me that I did not look at 
rtf, but I imagine there should be some Java classes for that.

pt.
